results.headline: A Corporate Big Shot With a Sideline in Art Theft

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Headhunters

results.summary_short: A corporate hunter also dabbles in art theft in this thriller.

results.headline: Who Loses and Who Profits When Sex Is a Commodity?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elles

results.summary_short: In “Elles” Juliette Binoche is a journalist working on an article about student prostitutes, who reveal another side to the job.

results.headline: A Beaten Teenager Seeks Solace in Another Species

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dolphin Boy

results.summary_short: An Arab teenager who is severely beaten after texting a girl in his class uses swimming with dolphins as a path to recovery in “Dolphin Boy,” a documentary set in Israel.

results.headline: Trailing Toronto’s War Veteran Turned Bank Robber

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Citizen Gangster

results.summary_short: “Citizen Gangster” is based on the true story of Edwin Boyd, the World War II veteran who became the most infamous bank robber in Canada.

results.headline: One Black Man’s Actions as a Piece of Civil Rights History

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Booker's Place: A Mississippi Story

results.summary_short: “Booker’s Place” is Raymond De Felitta’s documentary about the 1960s South, centering on the story of Booker Wright.

results.headline: Four Young People, One Crime and a Night Gone Wrong

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 96 Minutes

results.summary_short: A carjacking and one nightmarish ride full of panic and adrenaline shape the lives of four young people in “96 Minutes.”

results.headline: Why the Debt That Burdens the Modern World Is About More Than Money

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Payback

results.summary_short: “Payback,” a documentary by Jennifer Baichwal based on a book by Margaret Atwood, tries to show how debt extends far beyond the domain of money.

results.headline: Wandering Seoul in Patterns of Coincidence

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Day He Arrives

results.summary_short: In “The Day He Arrives” the director Hong Sang-soo illuminates how the present is haunted by the past.

results.headline: Trailing Her Heart, Pushpin by Pushpin

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goodbye First Love

results.summary_short: There is nothing ostentatious in “Goodbye First Love,” and also, remarkably, nothing false, except perhaps some of the hopes of the earnest young couple at its heart.

results.headline: Reggae’s Mellow King, Defined by a Legacy He Couldn’t Outrun

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marley

results.summary_short: In “Marley,” Kevin Macdonald’s documentary, Bob Marley’s life and art are defined by his attempt to reconcile his divided racial legacy.

results.headline: Hopscotching From One Block of Ice to the Next

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of To The Arctic 3D

results.summary_short: A 3-D documentary on polar bears, the Arctic and global warming features narration by Meryl Streep.

results.headline: Want That Ring? Let the Man Be a Man

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Think Like A Man

results.summary_short: “Think Like a Man” plays out variations on the relationship war. Thank goodness for Steve Harvey.

results.headline: This Vampire May Be Conjured From the Pages of a Book

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Moth Diaries

results.summary_short: The Moth Diaries,” a vampire tale, dances on the border between hallucination and reality without fully committing to either.

results.headline: A Well-Hydrated Romance, Courtesy of Nicholas Sparks

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lucky One

results.summary_short: “The Lucky One,” starring Zac Efron as a traumatized Iraq war veteran who walks to Louisiana, has all the trademarks of a Nicholas Sparks movie.

results.headline: Up Close and Very Personal: The Crimes That Pay a Man’s Way

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Snow on Tha Bluff

results.summary_short: “Snow on tha Bluff,” directed by Damon Russell, is just another “Blair Witch Project.” Or is it?

results.headline: Battlefield Friendship Through Violence of World War II

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Way

results.summary_short: In “My Way” the bloody chaos can be suitably overwhelming, but you’re too aware of the whizzing camerawork, helter-skelter editing and bombastic score.

results.headline: Drug War on Doorsteps All Over Ciudad Juárez

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Murder Capital of The World

results.summary_short: In “Murder Capital of the World,” all seem to agree that a surge of killings in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, ultimately stems from poverty and a lack of opportunity.

results.headline: New Meaning to the Term Rock Bottom

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jean Gentil

results.summary_short: “I’m always sad,” the hero of “Jean Gentil” says in this close-up of the Dominican Republic, with its skyscrapers and lush landscape in the countryside.

results.headline: Slice of Life in a Cage

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fightville

results.summary_short: “Fightville,” a documentary by Petra Epperlein and Michael Tucker, explores mixed martial arts and the men devoted to this few-holds-barred brand of fighting.

results.headline: New in Los Angeles, and Willing to Do Anything for Money

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Going Down in LA-LA Land

results.summary_short: “Going Down in La-La Land” is a familiar enough story of a young and beautiful person hoping to make it big in Hollywood only to attain disillusionment.
